questions.stem: Vertical infection includes which of the following?
questions.explanation: Vertical infection refers to the transmission of a pathogen from mother to child, which can occur in utero (during pregnancy), during delivery, or through breastfeeding. [cite: 19, 22, 113]

questions.stem: Which of the following is an example of Actively Acquired Natural Immunity?
questions.explanation: Actively acquired natural immunity develops when the body is exposed to a live pathogen, develops the disease (or a subclinical infection), and becomes immune as a result of the primary immune response. [cite: 24, 27, 113]

questions.stem: Which statement is true about the endemic spread of infectious diseases?
options: The disease is constantly present in the community.
All cases are interrelated regarding time and place.
There is an increased number of cases significantly more than the usual pattern.
questions.explanation: An endemic disease is one that is constantly present at a baseline level within a geographic area or population without external inputs. [cite: 29, 30, 113]

questions.stem: Which of the following is characteristic of carriers?
options: They are infectious and epidemiologically more dangerous than cases.
They never act as a source of infection.
They show no shedding of the infectious agent.
They have recognizable signs and symptoms.
questions.explanation: Carriers are epidemiologically dangerous because they are asymptomatic and not easily identified, allowing them to spread the infection unknowingly within the community. [cite: 37, 38, 113]

questions.stem: Which statement is true about seroprophylaxis?
options: It must be given before exposure.
There are no available human preparations.
It gives rapid but temporary protection.
questions.explanation: Seroprophylaxis involves administering pre-formed antibodies, which provides immediate, passive immunity that is short-lived. [cite: 47, 50, 113]

options: Supervision of contacts for the incubation period of the disease.
Contacts are excluded from school or work.
Contacts are isolated with concurrent disinfection.
questions.explanation: Segregation is the separation of individuals (contacts) who may have been exposed to an infectious disease from the general population, often by excluding them from public places like school or work, to monitor for illness. [cite: 56, 58, 113]

questions.stem: An anti-tetanus injection containing antibodies given for a contaminated wound is an example of:
questions.explanation: This is an example of seroprophylaxis (passive immunization), where pre-formed antibodies are given to prevent a disease from developing after a known exposure. [cite: 76, 77, 80, 113]

options: Data generated by reporting sources without request.
Collection of data for a relatively limited period of time by regular outreach.
Cross-sectional studies to determine the prevalence of selected diseases.
Cohort studies to define the incidence of selected diseases.
questions.explanation: Passive surveillance relies on healthcare providers and laboratories to report cases of disease on their own initiative, without active solicitation from health departments. [cite: 82, 83, 113]

questions.stem: Herd immunity occurs when the vaccination of a significant portion of a population provides protection for individuals who are not immune.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]This is the definition of herd immunity, where a high level of immunity in a population reduces the likelihood of infection for those with no immunity. [cite: 100, 113]

questions.stem: In biological transmission, insects play an active role in the transmission of infection from a reservoir to an exposed host.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]In biological transmission, the pathogen undergoes a part of its life cycle inside the vector (the insect), which is different from mechanical transmission where the insect is just a carrier. [cite: 100, 113]

questions.stem: Direct droplet infection can be transmitted by droplet nuclei and dust.
questions.explanation: False. Droplet nuclei and dust are responsible for INDIRECT transmission, as they can travel longer distances and remain suspended in the air for longer periods. [cite_start]Direct droplet transmission involves larger particles over a short distance. [cite: 100, 113]
